Content: Amalgamation of feline, bovid, and human parts
Therianthrope

Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Materials: Rock painting, charcoal and other natural pigments
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Function: Likely rituals designed to ensure a successful hunt
Content: Shows hunted animals in twisted perspective
Uses linear, infilled, and blended forms; formed by blowing pigment by mouth or carving into the rock

Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Term: Camelid sacrum in the shape of a canine
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Context: Many ancient cultures viewed this bone as sacred

Content: Depicts a ceremonially clothed figure (potentially a goddess)
Dotted area along body likely represents scarification
Context: This and similar pieces in the area were revealed by wetting their surface, which has faded the images
The area and piece were "discovered" by Henri Lhote, a French officer in 1933

Content: Divided into several bands/registers with stylized animals
Shows domesticated and traditional hunter-gatherer animals
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Context: Found in a tightly packed cemetery which was filled with second burials

Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Content: Abstract robed figure with a necklace, awl, belt, and dagger
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Context: Cemetery; the design's similarity to others shows the region's early caravan trade routes

Content: Tubular object with a circular hole and squarish cross section
Different shapes symbolize realms or animals (dragon faces)
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Context: Found around bodies in graves, alongside bi disks

Content: Set of megaliths arranged in a 108 ft (diameter circle)
30 sarsen stones capped with 30 lintel stones, arrangement of bluestones
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Context: Built in three phases, going from a large circular ditch to a burial site to its modern form

Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Function: Mortar and pestle, later ancestral object
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Culture: Enga Province, Neolithic Papua New Guinea
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Context: Prior to their conversion to Christianity, the Enga people used it to represent ancestors

Content: Bicephalic female figure
Shows wide hips and a focus on hairstyle (valued by the civilization)
Unit 1: Global Prehistory.Context: Male figures from this culture were rare, and focused on religious and ritual expertise
The designs and motifs on these pieces trace the movement of Lapita culture over time

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Religious center and location of pilgramages
Content: Architectural complex with a sunken circular plaza, terraces, and a labyrinthine network of underground galleries
Lanzón Stela depicts animalistic deity with feline features
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Context: Built in two phases, with a U-shaped Old Temple and a New Temple with a sunken court

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Shows allegiance to the Chavín religion
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Content: Two snake heads pointing out of a gold disk with spirals

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Housed ~250 people, domestic/civic space, and cross-clan meeting area
Content: Carved out of the cliff face, with 150 rooms and 23 kivas
Round ritual spaces (kivas) had sipapu (hole to the underworld)
Many ceramics and wall paintings found in the dwellings
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Context: Abandoned due to drought and resource depletion; Rediscovered in 1888 by Richard Wetherill and heavily looted

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Civic space demonstrating political power and legitimacy; religious and economic center
Content: Complex of over 100 structures, monuments, and temples
Walls built with a slight inward curve, carvings and inscruptions inside and outside
Structure #33: roog comb and lintels with hieroglyphic inscriptions
Lintel #25: bas relief of the bloodletting ritual of a principal wife
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Context: Lintel reliefs were meant to be informative and show history, as well as transition between the real and spirtual worlds

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Ceremonial and likely astronomical use (possibly related to moon phases)
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Content: 1300 ft long mound of dirt raised 3 ft high
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Culture: Adams County, southern Ohio. Mississippian (Eastern Woodlands)
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Context: May have been built by the Fort Ancient culture, and is one of the largest effigy mounds in the world

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Axis Mundi; dedicated to Huitzilopochtli (god of war) and Tlaloc (god of rain)
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Content: Stepped pyramid with two shrines at the top
Context: Rebuilt seven times, on top of itself, with each layer being added by a different ruler
Destroyed and looted by the Spanish in 1521 CE

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Content: Stone monolith depicting a dismembered moon goddess; 11 ft diameter, 12 in thick
Context: The moon goddess was killed by her brother, Huitzilopochtli, and thrown down the temple stairs after she attempted to kill their mother
A similar object existed in the same location in every rendition of the temple

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Buried by thr Mexica in a ritual offering
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Content: 4 in tall face with a cleft head, almond-shaped eyes, and upturned lips
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Context: Belonged to an older culture that the Mexica admired and emulated

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Content: 12 ft (diameter) disk with a sun god face in the center, surrounded by four squares and many concentric bands of design

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Function: Display of wealth and power; worn ritually with further apparel
Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Content: Three general bands of feathers; softer blue in the center, a gold band, and teal feathers on the outside
Context: Probably of Motecuhzoma II; sent to Europe by Cortés after conquering Tenotchtitlan
Quetzal feathers were often given as tribute by conquered peoples

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Term: City of Cusco, including Qorikancha (Inka main temple), Domingo (Spanish colonial convent), and Walls at Saqsa Waman (Sacsayhuaman)

Unit 5: Indigenous Americas.Culture: Eastern Shoshone, Wind River Reservation, Wyoming
Tewa, Puebloan, San Ildefonso Pueblo, New Mexico

Unit 6: Africa.Materials: Coursed granite blocks with no mortar
Function: Conical tower may have served as a granary
Content: Hill Complex, Great Enclosure, and Valley Enclosures
Over 800 ft of wall, over 32 ft high and 17 ft thick at base
Context: Prospered from cattle herding, gold mining, and Indian Ocean trade
May have declined due to environmental fragility, political instability, or livestock diseases

Content: Hypostyle hall, three minarets, and a flat roof
Ostrich eggs placed on minarets to symbolize purity
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Is re-plastered annually in the festival of Crépissage de la Grand Mosquée

Unit 6: Africa.Function: Showed the lineage and history of the Benin kingdom
Content: King flanked by attendants and Portuguese traders
Hierarchical scale, the king is the largest figure
Panel made with the lost wax casting technique
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Portuguese traders exchanged brass and coral for pepper, cloth, and stone beads

Unit 6: Africa.Materials: Gold over wood and cast-gold attachments
Unit 6: Africa.Function: Represents the soul of the Ashanti people
Content: Has a flat seat and two curved legs
Accompanied by golden bells
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Ashanti believe that it fell from the heavens into the lap of their first king

Content: Depicts King Mishe miShyaang maMbul as an ideal ruler - calm, intelligent, and meditative
Has a serene expression and an oversized head
Wearing a crown, arm bands, and sits cross legged on a stool
Unit 6: Africa.Culture: Kuba peoples (Democratic Republic of the Congo)
Unit 6: Africa.Context: The held drum has an motif that identifies the ruler

Function: Stores herbs and medicine in the chest cavity
Acts as a judicial authority (pegs driven into the figure to seal agreements)
Content: Human figure 4 ft tall with a chest cavity (mooyo)
Covered in metal spikes and nails
Unit 6: Africa.Culture: Konga peoples (Democratic Republic of the Congo)
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Believed to hold a spirit that blessed or cursed individuals to enforce contracts

Unit 6: Africa.Function: Worn by men in initiation ceremonies of adolescent boys
Unit 6: Africa.Content: White pigment around the eyes signifies the spirit realm; closed eyes and mouth
Unit 6: Africa.Culture: Chokwe peoples (Democratic Republic of the Congo)
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Perceived as spirits of deceased; presents ideal womanhood

Unit 6: Africa.Function: Used in dances to honor individuals
Content: Triangle marks on forehead and cheeks, a stretched face
Squinted eyes and high forehead show wisdom and modesty; carved hair and tubular crown
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Commissioned by the husband of Moya Yanso, a prolific dancer

Unit 6: Africa.Function: Worn by women in girl's initiation ceremonies; displays an ideal to be mimicked
Unit 6: Africa.Content: High forehead, downcast eyes, and a small mouth; elaborate coiffure
Unit 6: Africa.Context: West African forests of Sierra Leone and Liberia; represents ideal womanhood

Unit 6: Africa.Function: Expression of power, warrior status, and personal achievement or success
Content: Very abstract anthropomorphic figure with a horned headdress; covered in geometric patterns
Two vertical horns display power, strength, and aggression
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Received upon a male's coming of age; buried with its owner

Unit 6: Africa.Function: Mnemonic device for oral history, genealogy, and cosmology
Content: Board with beads and shells attached in patterns
Geometric zoomorphic texture along the side and back
Unit 6: Africa.Culture: Luba peoples (Democratic Republic of the Congo)
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Interpreted exclusively by members of the Mbudye Society

Unit 6: Africa.Materials: Wood, woven raffia, cloth, and beads
Unit 6: Africa.Function: Worn for important ceremonial events, along with a full costume (leopard skin on back and conical headdress)
Unit 6: Africa.Content: Horror vacui design with a repeating geometric pattern; large ears, trunk in front, and flap on back
Unit 6: Africa.Context: Elephants are symbols of power and authority; masks are worn by the Kuosi society

Unit 6: Africa.Function: Guarded and protected a box storing the bones of community members, medicine, and beads
Unit 6: Africa.Content: Calm and serene face with a high forehead, downcast eyes, and a small mouth; elaborate coiffure and elongated torso
Unit 6: Africa.Context: The figure was placed on top of the box; warriors, skilled craftsmen, abd leaders valued

Unit 6: Africa.Term: Opo Ogoga (veranda post of enthroned king and senior wife)
Unit 6: Africa.Function: Structural post of the palace porch
Content: Consists of two central figures and three smaller attendants (one missing)
Crown has four faces and a bird on top representing transformational abilities and protection
Context: The parallel facial marks and scarification patterns identify lineage and status (respectively)
Filing of teeth was a sign of beauty and rank; elaborate hairstyle worn for special occasions

Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Capital of the Saudeleur Dynasty; ceremonial center
Unit 9: The Pacific.Content: Complex of around 100 artificial islets with mortuary, religious, and residential sections
Unit 9: The Pacific.Context: The 1,850 tons of basalt were assembled without mortar, and with a population of less than 30,000

Unit 9: The Pacific.Materials: Volcanic tuff figures on basalt base
Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Honor a passed chief and protect the islanders
Content: Large, 14 ft tall figures, weighing several tons
Some figures had coral eyes and red volcanic stone hats
Always faced inland (with one exception)
Unit 9: The Pacific.Context: Carvings on the back were added by the later birdman cult

Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Worn ceremonially and in battle by Hawaiian chiefs; gifted as a sign of respect
Unit 9: The Pacific.Content: Contained thousands of feathers from rare birds
Context: Symbol of power and status; was gifted to Captain Cook and other European visitors
Made from feathers of the i'iwi bird, which was considered sacred by the Hawaiians

Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Religious artifact; represented deities and ancestors; protects and contains mana
Content: Carved wooden figure with a tapa cloth wrapped around it
Wooden shaft has small figures on one side and a feathered pendant
Unit 9: The Pacific.Context: Combines male and female elements; wood core made by men and barkcloth covering by women

Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Sacred object representing a deity; centerpiece of ceremonies
Content: Wooden sculpture with an ovoid head, pointy chin, tall chest, and short legs
Has minimal personal features, but was dressed/decorated in temples
Context: Each figure had a specific name to associated with a family group, priest, and temple
Central place in a religious harvest ceremony; harvested fruits and food offerings brought to it

Unit 9: The Pacific.Materials: Turtle shell, wood, fiber, feathers, and shell
Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Worn along with a full-body costume for dances and ceremonies
Content: Displays a human face below a frigate bird
Rafia fibers mimic human hair, and shells are used for eyes
Context: Most of these masks were destroyed by missionaries in the 19th century
Human face may have represented heroes or ancestors, while the frigate bird may have been a totem

Unit 9: The Pacific.Materials: Tapa or bark cloth, freehand painting
Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Clothing, bedding, and wall hangings; displayed ceremonially
Unit 9: The Pacific.Content: Concentric circles divided radially with organic (leaves/flowers), and geometric designs
Unit 9: The Pacific.Context: Typically, these cloths were made by women

Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Displayed in Māori homes and European museums, created for profit
Content: Depicted in traditional clothing - cloak of kiwi feathers, greenstone pendant, and a tiki (weapon)
Emphasis on figure through yellow lighting - glows against the background
Depicts facial tattoo - lines and swirls
Context: Painting was based off of a photograph of the chief, and was commissioned by a European buyer
Māori paintings embody the ancestor they depict

Function: Used to memorize routes on land, but not navigate
Map that marks island locations, currents, and wave patterns
Unit 9: The Pacific.Content: Shells mark island locations, diagonal and curved sticks mark ocean swells and currents

Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Displayed in mortuary rituals to represent the deceased
Content: Include depictions of animals, birds, and fish; colored with a red, blue, and white palette
Have highly textured surfaces, especially in the face carving and hair
Unit 9: The Pacific.Culture: New Ireland Province, Papua New Guinea
Unit 9: The Pacific.Context: Brought into the social world during the dry season, in mortuary rituals

Unit 9: The Pacific.Term: Presentation of Fijian mats and tapa cloths to Queen Elizabeth II
Unit 9: The Pacific.Materials: Multimedia performance (costume; cosmetics, including scent; chant; movement; and pandanus fiber/hibiscus fiber mats), photographic documentation
Unit 9: The Pacific.Function: Gift to the Queen; performance of Fijian culture
Unit 9: The Pacific.Content: Women wearing barkcloth skirts painted with geometric patterns; mats contain simple geometric pattern (functional)
Unit 9: The Pacific.Context: Taken during a royal tour of the British Commonwealth in 1953
